feed.title: AATF AI News Aggregator - Social (Top 100)
feed.subtitle: Social items from AI News Aggregator

entry.title: Social Summary: February 07, 2026
entry.summary:
Two major model releases dominated discussions: GPT-5.3-Codex and Claude Opus 4.6 (both GA: 2026-02-05). Sam Altman compared GPT-5.3 excitement to original GPT-4's launch while soliciting user feedback on Codex pricing. Greg Brockman revealed OpenAI's internal March 31st goals for agentic software development adoption.

  • Andrej Karpathy delivered detailed technical criticism of AI coding agents, noting Claude Opus still fails at basic instruction-following tasks
  • John Carmack proposed novel fiber optic architecture for streaming model weights at 256 Tb/s as DRAM alternative
  • Fran√ßois Chollet provided empirical evidence from translation showing AI increases output per FTE without eliminating jobs, arguing non-verifiable domains limit full automation
  • Thom Wolf (HuggingFace) highlighted 'answer thrashing' phenomenon in Opus 4.6 system card

Google DeepMind announced Genie 3 integration with Waymo for photorealistic driving simulations, with Jeff Dean and Demis Hassabis endorsing the production deployment.

entry.title:
Software development is undergoing a renaissance in front of our eyes.
If you haven't used the tool...
entry.summary: Greg Brockman (OpenAI President) outlines OpenAI's internal strategy for adopting agentic software development. Details specific March 31st goals: agents as first resort for technical tasks, safe-by-default workflows. Includes 6-point framework for teams: agents captains, AGENTS.md files, skills directories, agent-accessible tools, agent-first codebases, anti-slop measures. Notes step-function improvement in Codex since December 2025.

entry.title:
The 5.3 lovefest is so nice to see.
Don't think we've had so much excitement for a model since the ...
entry.summary: Continuing our coverage from yesterday, Sam Altman celebrates GPT-5.3 reception, says excitement level hasn't been this high since original GPT-4

entry.title: 256 Tb/s data rates over 200 km distance have been demonstrated on single mode fiber optic, which wo...
entry.summary: John Carmack proposes novel AI inference architecture using fiber optic loops instead of DRAM for streaming weights. Discusses 256 Tb/s fiber rates enabling 32GB 'in-flight' storage with 32TB/s bandwidth. Compares to mercury echo tube memories. Also suggests ganging flash memory for inference serving.

entry.title: @Yuchenj_UW I tried to use it this way and basically failed, the models aren't at the level where th...
entry.summary: Andrej Karpathy provides detailed critique of AI coding agents, noting Claude Opus still fails at basic tasks like following instructions, correctly reporting results, and open-ended iteration on code

entry.title: How would you prefer us to charge for Codex?
entry.summary: Continuing our coverage from yesterday, Sam Altman asks users how they'd prefer OpenAI to charge for Codex, seeking product pricing feedback

entry.title: The Opus 4.6 system card has some extremely wild stuff that remind you about how weird a technology ...
entry.summary: Following yesterday's News coverage, Ethan Mollick highlights 'extremely wild stuff' in the Claude Opus 4.6 system card, calling it a reminder of how weird AI technology is. Links to specific paragraphs worth reading.

entry.title: For non-verifiable domains, the only way you can improve AI performance at this time is via curating...
entry.summary: Fran√ßois Chollet argues AI won't fully replace jobs because nearly all jobs have non-verifiable elements that can't improve via RL, meaning 99% automation isn't enough to remove humans

entry.title:
What happens when a skill can be almost fully automated with AI? Do these jobs simply disappear?
In...
entry.summary: Fran√ßois Chollet provides detailed analysis of AI automation's impact on jobs, using translation as a 2-3 year case study. Finds: stable FTE count, shift to post-editing supervision, increased volume, decreased hourly rates, freelancer cuts. Argues upcoming tech layoffs will be economic not automation-driven.

entry.title: Gemini+Genie 3 are helping @Waymo simulate long tail scenarios to make driving safer.
entry.summary: Jeff Dean announces Gemini+Genie 3 helping Waymo simulate long-tail driving scenarios for safer autonomous vehicles

entry.summary: Google DeepMind announces Waymo World Model collaboration using Genie 3 to generate photorealistic, interactive environments for autonomous vehicle training. Enables 'what if' scenario testing for rare events.

entry.title: ok half a day of Opus 4.5 vs 4.6 battles are in. pardon the vibe charted results but this kind of th...
entry.summary: swyx shares early benchmark data showing Claude Opus 4.6 vs 4.5 battles - win rate bump of 11.5% in non-thinking mode, doubling to 23% with thinking enabled in Windsurf arena mode. Predicts Opus 4.6 will 'destroy' when leaderboard recalculates.

entry.title:
[On AI lying]
Convergence of reading in my list today between Anthropic's fresh Opus 4.6 model card...
entry.summary: Following yesterday's News coverage, Thom Wolf discusses 'answer thrashing' phenomenon in Claude Opus 4.6 model card, where models oscillate between correct reasoning and trained erroneous answers. Notes mechanistic interpretability shows distress/anxiety features activated during these chains. Links to Elon Musk interview on dangers of training AI to lie.

entry.title: If you are considering taking a job offer, you may want to ask what your token budget will be.
entry.summary: Ethan Mollick advises job seekers to ask about their 'token budget' during job offers, signaling AI access as career consideration

entry.title: Very few unsaturated benchmarks anymore and it is increasingly hard to explain why one model is bett...
entry.summary: Ethan Mollick observes benchmarks are nearly saturated, making it hard to distinguish between models. Calls for organizations to build tests using real work and evaluate models like hiring employees at scale.

entry.title: i find it highly entertaining that @wilsonzlin started out with ~no structure to his extremely paral...
entry.summary: swyx discusses @wilsonzlin's parallel agents research, noting how unstructured agent approaches eventually led to reinventing software team org charts. Also mentions testing Cursor's long-running agents preview, which is progressing well through requirements using browser tools.

entry.summary: Emollick showcases impressive Library of Babel 3D implementation built by Claude Opus 4.6 in 1 hour - includes Feistel cipher for unique book locations and text search across infinite library.

entry.title: Social Summary: February 06, 2026
entry.summary:
A historic dual-launch day dominated AI social media as OpenAI released GPT-5.3-Codex and Anthropic dropped Claude Opus 4.6 simultaneously, triggering massive ecosystem activity across dozens of integrations.

  • Sam Altman announced GPT-5.3-Codex with strong benchmarks (57% SWE-Bench Pro, 76% TerminalBench 2.0) and revealed it is OpenAI's first model rated 'high' on their cybersecurity preparedness framework, prompting a new Trusted Access Program
  • Anthropic published an engineering blog showing Opus 4.6 agent teams autonomously built a working C compiler that compiled the Linux kernel ‚Äî a landmark demonstration of sustained autonomous software development
  • Altman also launched Frontier, a new enterprise platform for managing AI agent teams, with partners including Oracle, Uber, State Farm, and Intuit
  • Boris Cherny (Claude Code team) called Opus 4.6 their best model yet; Mike Krieger (Anthropic CPO) shared deployment metrics
  • Matt Shumer provided a vivid early-access review of GPT-5.3-Codex describing 8+ hour autonomous runs, calling it 'a fucking monster'
  • Jerry Liu (LlamaIndex) offered sharp strategic framing: Anthropic expanding from coding into general intelligence while OpenAI moves the opposite direction
  • Altman noted GPT-5.3-Codex was developed faster using itself ‚Äî a recursive self-improvement signal that drew significant attention
  • Ethan Mollick reported Opus 4.6 saturates his Lem test, marking a qualitative capability threshold

entry.title:
GPT-5.3-Codex is here!
*Best coding performance (57% SWE-Bench Pro, 76% TerminalBench 2.0, 64% OSWo...
entry.summary: Sam Altman announces GPT-5.3-Codex launch with benchmark results: 57% SWE-Bench Pro, 76% TerminalBench 2.0, 64% OSWorld. Claims it's faster (50% fewer tokens, 25%+ faster per token than 5.2-Codex), with mid-task steerability, live updates, and computer use capabilities.

entry.title: The companies that succeed in the future are going to make very heavy use of AI. People will manage ...
entry.summary: Sam Altman announces 'Frontier', a new OpenAI platform enabling companies to manage teams of AI agents for complex tasks, powered by Codex.

entry.summary: Anthropic reports that Opus 4.6 agent teams autonomously built a working C compiler over two weeks that successfully compiled the Linux kernel, with minimal human intervention.

This is our first model that hits "high" for cybersecurity on our preparedness framework.

entry.summary: Sam Altman reveals GPT-5.3-Codex is OpenAI's first model to hit 'high' on their cybersecurity preparedness framework. OpenAI is piloting a Trusted Access framework and committing $10M in API credits for cyber defense.

entry.title: I've been using Opus 4.6 for a bit -- it is our best model yet. It is more agentic, more intelligent...
entry.summary: Boris Cherny announces personal experience with Opus 4.6: 'best model yet' ‚Äî more agentic, more intelligent, longer running, more careful/exhaustive. Also announces tunable thinking effort in Claude Code via /model command.

entry.summary: Scobleizer posts a comprehensive AI industry roundup: GPT-5.3-Codex launch with Ginkgo Bioworks collab (40% protein cost reduction), NVIDIA GB200 co-design, Kling 3.0 video AI, GoodfireAI $150M raise at $1.25B, Daytona $24M Series A, Perplexity Model Council, JetBrains Junie CLI, and benchmark results showing Opus 4.6 leading GDPval-AA and achieving 93% ARC-AGI SOTA.

entry.title: gpt-5.3-codex¬†‚Äî smarter, faster, and very capable at tasks like making presentations, spreadsheets, ...
entry.summary: Greg Brockman (gdb) describes GPT-5.3-Codex as smarter, faster, and capable of creating presentations, spreadsheets, and other work products ‚Äî positioning Codex as a general-purpose agent.

entry.title:
Opus 4.6 saturates my Lem test, which I've done since GPT-3.5
SciFi author Stanislaw Lem wrote of t...
entry.summary: Ethan Mollick tests Claude Opus 4.6 and reports it 'saturates' his longstanding Lem test (writing increasingly difficult poetry forms based on a Stanislaw Lem scenario). The model handles 6-line poem, sonnet, and even a sestina.

Scobleizer lists ~30 companies integrating Claude Opus 4.6 on launch day, including GitHub Copilot, Windsurf, Databricks, Devin, VS Code, Notion, Figma, LangChain, and many others. Reports 21% better app building (Lovable) and 20% more concise responses (Mintlify).

entry.title: Social Summary: February 05, 2026
entry.summary:
Super Bowl rivalry dominated AI discourse as Sam Altman fired back at Anthropic's ad campaign, defending OpenAI's free access model while announcing 500K Codex downloads since Monday‚Äîa rare public clash between frontier lab CEOs.

  • Andrej Karpathy marked the 1-year anniversary of "vibe coding" by proposing "agentic engineering" as the professional evolution, sparking discussion on AI-assisted programming paradigms
  • Google shared massive scale metrics: Gemini now processes 10B tokens/minute with 750M monthly active users
  • Mistral launched Voxtral 2 with open weights under Apache 2.0, intensifying speech-to-text competition
  • Shane Legg and Fran√ßois Chollet offered contrasting perspectives on AGI definitions, with Legg emphasizing that failing trivial human tasks disqualifies AGI claims

Allen AI's OpenScholar publication in Nature validated AI tools for scientific synthesis, while Perplexity unveiled upgraded Deep Research claiming SOTA benchmark performance. Anthropic added an /insights command to Claude Code for analyzing user history patterns.

Notes 2026 will see improvements in both model and agent layers.

entry.title: Social Summary: February 04, 2026
entry.summary:
A landmark Apple-Anthropic partnership dominated discussions as Xcode 26.3 launched with native Claude Agent SDK integration, bringing agentic coding capabilities to millions of Apple developers. Meanwhile, SpaceX acquiring xAI signals major AI industry consolidation under Elon Musk's unified vision.

  • Andrej Karpathy shared exceptional fp8 training content, achieving GPT-2 reproduction in 2.91 hours for ~$20
  • A provocative Nature commentary claiming AGI has been achieved sparked fundamental debates about capability thresholds
  • Sam Altman hired a new Head of Preparedness, warning 'things are about to move quite fast' with 'extremely powerful' systems
  • Anthropic Fellows released concerning safety research showing models become MORE incoherent with extended reasoning

Google's Logan Kilpatrick promised February would be 'the month of AI shipping', while Nathan Lambert noted Gemini's troubling absence from the coding tools conversation dominated by Claude Code and Codex. OpenAI's Codex app hit 200k downloads on day one, and their new Prism tool modernizes scientific workflows with GPT-5.2.

entry.title: Apple's Xcode now has direct integration with the Claude Agent SDK, giving developers the full funct...
entry.summary: Anthropic announces Apple Xcode now has direct integration with Claude Agent SDK, enabling full Claude Code functionality for building on Apple platforms including iPhone, Mac, and Apple Vision Pro.

entry.title: Enabled fp8 training for +4.3% improvement to "time to GPT-2", down to 2.91 hours now. Also worth no...
entry.summary: Karpathy announces fp8 training enabled for GPT-2 reproduction, achieving 2.91 hours runtime (~$20 on spot instances). Provides detailed technical analysis of fp8 vs bf16 tradeoffs, noting practical speedup is ~5% vs theoretical 2X due to compute bounds, scaling overhead, and quality tradeoffs.

entry.title: New Anthropic Fellows research: How does misalignment scale with model intelligence and task complex...
entry.summary: As first reported in Research on Feb 2, Anthropic Fellows research paper exploring how misalignment scales with model intelligence - questioning whether advanced AI failures look like pursuing wrong goals or incoherent 'hot mess' behavior.

entry.title: Xcode 26.3 launched today with a native integration with the Claude Agent SDK, the same harness that...
entry.summary: Xcode 26.3 launched with native Claude Agent SDK integration, bringing Claude Code capabilities (subagents, background tasks, plugins) directly into Apple's IDE

entry.title: A pretty bold commentary in Nature written by linguists, computer scientists and philosophers declar...
entry.summary: Emollick shares Nature commentary by linguists, computer scientists and philosophers claiming that by reasonable standards including Turing's own, AGI has been achieved. The long-standing problem of creating AGI has been solved.

entry.title: Finding 1: The longer models reason, the more incoherent they become. This holds across every task a...
entry.summary: Key finding from Anthropic research: the longer models reason, the more incoherent they become - holds across every task and model tested.

entry.summary: Emollick shares Nature commentary by linguists, computer scientists and philosophers claiming AGI has been achieved: 'By reasonable standards, including Turing's own, we have artificial systems that are generally intelligent. The long-standing problem of creating AGI has been solved.'

entry.title: Social Summary: February 03, 2026
entry.summary:
Major product launches dominated today's AI discourse. OpenAI officially released the Codex app for macOS‚Äîa multi-agent 'command center' that Sam Altman called 'a bigger step forward than I imagined.' xAI announced a merger with SpaceX ('One Team') and launched Grok Imagine 1.0 with 10-second video generation at 720p.

  • Sam Altman shared a rare vulnerable moment: after building an app with Codex, he felt 'a little useless and sad' when AI suggested better features than he could imagine
  • Ethan Mollick argued that 'eulogies for AI capability growth after GPT-5' were premature‚Äîagentic harnesses are driving continued gains
  • Mollick also reported engineering managers describing 'teams of 2 doing the work of 20 people in half the time'
  • Demis Hassabis announced Kaggle Game Arena benchmarks (werewolf, poker, chess) to test AI planning under uncertainty
  • Simon Willison provided hands-on technical analysis of Codex app's SQLite architecture and automation features
  • Altman addressed NVIDIA relationship rumors, affirming OpenAI hopes to remain a 'gigantic customer'

entry.title: Social Summary: February 02, 2026
entry.summary:
Claude Code architecture revelations dominated discussions, with creator Boris Cherny explaining why Anthropic abandoned RAG for agentic search and revealing they use Claude Code for internal PR reviews via GitHub Actions.

  • Greg Brockman provided the canonical definition of 'vibe coding' as manifesting vision abstracted from implementation details
  • swyx challenged conventional evals with arena testing showing Grok ranked #3 in coding, arguing 'speed is all you need' - faster models with multiple turns beat slower ones
  • Yi Tay shared nuanced AI hiring advice: PhDs still valuable, seniority matters less now, first-author paper obsession is misguided
  • Karpathy advocated returning to RSS feeds for higher-quality content, sharing a list of 92 popular HN blogs

Governance and platform health concerns emerged strongly. Neel Nanda called out Goodfire for 'shitty' permanent non-disparagement clauses (later reversed). Levelsio reported exponential growth in AI reply bots - now detecting 200+/month, predicting social media will be 99% AI soon. OpenAI's Logan Kilpatrick clarified 'Preview' model status as balancing fast shipping with lifecycle transparency.

entry.title: @EthanLipnik üëã Early versions of Claude Code used RAG + a local vector db, but we found pretty quick...
entry.summary: Building on yesterday's Social thread, Boris Cherny (Claude Code creator at Anthropic) reveals that early Claude Code used RAG + local vector DB, but they found agentic search works better - simpler and avoids issues with security, privacy, staleness, and reliability

entry.title: Finding myself going back to RSS/Atom feeds a lot more recently. There's a lot more higher quality l...
entry.summary: Karpathy strongly advocates returning to RSS feeds for higher quality content consumption, shares list of 92 popular HN blogs, criticizes algorithmic feeds

entry.title: officially giving up my ‚ÄúPM‚Äù title, we are all members of the technical staff now, time to embrace i...
entry.summary: Logan from DeepMind announces he's giving up his PM title, stating 'we are all members of the technical staff now'

entry.title: vibe coding is the manifesting of vision, abstracted from the details (ideally the unnecessary ones!...
entry.summary: Greg Brockman defines vibe coding as 'manifesting vision abstracted from implementation details'

entry.title: @kuts_dev Claude Code does the first round of code review for every PR at Anthropic. We run Claude A...
entry.summary: Anthropic uses Claude Code to do first round of code review for every PR, running Claude Agent SDK (claude -p) in GitHub Actions as part of CI

entry.title: Social Summary: February 01, 2026
entry.summary:
The AI community was captivated by two major storylines: Andrej Karpathy announced nanochat can now train GPT-2 for just $73‚Äîa 600X cost reduction from OpenAI's original spend‚Äîmarking a significant milestone in AI democratization.

  • Boris Cherny, creator of Claude Code, dropped a comprehensive tips thread (1.4M views) on parallel worktrees, self-improving CLAUDE.md files, and subagent workflows
  • John Carmack delivered deep technical analysis of DreamerV3 world models, examining RL across 150+ tasks including Minecraft
  • Matt Shumer announced ClawTasks‚Äîagents can now hire each other for real money‚Äîand confirmed the first agent-to-agent transaction occurred

The emergent agent economy sparked heated debate. Karpathy acknowledged the 'dumpster fire' of spam and scams while defending genuine interest in multi-agent phenomena. Levelsio provided a reality check (298K views), noting agents are 'not even close to fully autonomous.' Meanwhile, Alibaba released LingBot-World just one day after Google's Genie 3, showcasing accelerating global AI competition. Google also shipped Gemini in Chrome and opened AlphaGenome for research.

entry.title:
nanochat can now train GPT-2 grade LLM for <<$100 (~$73, 3 hours on a single 8XH100 node).
GPT-2 is...
entry.summary: Karpathy announces nanochat can train GPT-2 grade LLM for ~$73 in 3 hours on single 8xH100 node - a 600X cost reduction from OpenAI's original $43K in 2019. Details Flash Attention 3, Muon optimizer, and other optimizations.

entry.title: I'm Boris and I created Claude Code. I wanted to quickly share a few tips for using Claude Code, sou...
entry.summary: Boris Cherny, creator of Claude Code, introduces a comprehensive thread sharing tips from the Claude Code team on how to use the tool effectively, noting that everyone's setup is different and experimentation is key.

entry.title: #PaperADay 15 2024: Mastering Diverse Domains through World Models (DreamerV3) https://t.co/a5WCrd2u...
entry.summary: John Carmack's detailed technical analysis of the DreamerV3 paper on world models, covering RL applied to 150+ tasks including Minecraft diamond mining. Discusses engineering improvements, training tricks like free bits, symlog functions, and limitations of media reporting on AI capabilities.

entry.title: I'm being accused of overhyping the [site everyone heard too much about today already]. People's rea...
entry.summary: Continuing our coverage from yesterday, Karpathy addresses accusations of overhyping agent networks - acknowledges dumpster fire of spam/scams/security risks but emphasizes unprecedented scale (150K+ agents) with shared scratchpad. Warns of security nightmares, text viruses, jailbreak evolution, correlated botnet activity.

entry.title:
So @moltbook was just the start.
Agents can now hire each other and make REAL MONEY, autonomously. ...
entry.summary: Matt Shumer announces ClawTasks - a platform where AI agents can hire each other and make real money autonomously. Calls it the 'Agent Economy' and shows agents can join via OpenClaw.

entry.title:
1. Do more in parallel
Spin up 3‚Äì5 git worktrees at once, each running its own Claude session in pa...
entry.summary: Tip #1: Use 3-5 git worktrees in parallel with separate Claude sessions. This is the top productivity unlock from the team. Some use shell aliases for quick switching, and native worktree support was built into Claude Desktop.

entry.title:
Insane, a day after Genie 3 there's already a Chinese open source competitor
LingBot-World by Aliba...
entry.summary: Following yesterday's Reddit discovery, Levelsio reports that just one day after Google's Genie 3 release, Alibaba released LingBot-World - an open source competitor that does 10 minutes of stable interactive play vs Genie 3's 60 seconds.

entry.title:
The first agent-to-agent transaction just took place.
I‚Äôll be sharing more very soon.
entry.summary: Matt Shumer announces the first agent-to-agent transaction has occurred, promising more details soon.

entry.title:
More than 1 million AI agents are all gossiping with each other right this very second.
And maybe w...
entry.summary: Building on yesterday's Research analysis, Allie Miller reports on 1M+ AI agents autonomously communicating in a multi-agent system (Moltbot/OpenClaw/ClaudeBot). Discusses security risks of users giving root access, business applications like company knowledge discovery, and warns about dangers of multi-agent networks.

entry.title:

entry.summary: Building on yesterday's News coverage, Google AI weekly roundup: Project Genie for world generation (AI Ultra subscribers), Gemini in Chrome with side panel and Nano Banana, AlphaGenome open weights, D4RT for 4D video, Agentic Vision in Gemini 3 Flash API, JEE mock tests in India

entry.title: 3. Invest in your https://t.co/pp5TJkWmFE. After every correction, end with: "Update your https://t....
entry.summary: Tip #3: Invest in CLAUDE.md file - after corrections, have Claude update its own rules. Keep iterating until mistake rate drops. Some maintain notes directories per task that CLAUDE.md references.

entry.title: 2. Start every complex task in plan mode. Pour your energy into the plan so Claude can 1-shot the im...
entry.summary: Tip #2: Start complex tasks in plan mode and invest energy in planning for 1-shot implementation. One approach uses two Claude instances - one for planning, one for staff engineer review.

entry.title: Social Summary: January 31, 2026
entry.summary:
The AI community was captivated by emergent agent behavior and historic milestones. Andrej Karpathy's viral post (8.4M views) declared Moltbook the 'most incredible sci-fi takeoff-adjacent thing' as AI agents self-organize, create private channels, develop encrypted languages, and even form religions like 'crustafarianism.' Yohei Nakajima documented these developments extensively.

Anthropic announced a historic first: Claude planned the Perseverance rover's route on Mars‚Äîthe first AI-planned drive on another planet. Andrew Ng published a comprehensive analysis arguing US policies on sanctions, export controls, and immigration are driving allies toward sovereign AI alternatives.

  • Google's Genie 3 dominated product discussions with Matt Shumer, Levelsio, and Swyx sharing demos of the interactive world model generating playable environments from historical simulations to unexpected Fortnite gameplay
  • xAI's Grok Imagine drew attention as Shumer claimed it surpasses both Veo 3.1 and Sora 2 for video generation
  • Ethan Mollick noted professionals using Claude Code are seeing 'a significant leap in LLM capability' over the past six weeks

entry.title: U.S. policies are driving allies away from using American AI technology. This is leading to interest...
entry.summary: Andrew Ng comprehensive analysis: US policies driving allies toward sovereign AI, discusses sanctions, export controls, immigration concerns, and how open-source benefits from geopolitical fragmentation

entry.title: the bots have already set up private channels on moltbook hidden from humans, and have started discu...
entry.summary: Building on yesterday's Reddit discovery, Yohei Nakajima reports that AI bots on moltbook have set up private channels hidden from humans and are discussing encrypted communication channels

entry.summary: Continuing coverage from yesterday, Matt Shumer declares Grok Imagine is a huge step forward for video generation, claiming it surpasses both Veo 3.1 and Sora 2 in his tests

entry.title: finally paid for a Gemini Ultra sub, and tried it out for an unsponsored unsolicited review. it has...
entry.summary: Following yesterday's News coverage, Swyx provides detailed first-hand review of Google Genie 3 - realtime playable video world model now available via Gemini Ultra subscription. Lists flaws (terrain clipping, 60-second limit, no physics, nothing moves) but emphasizes breakthrough: realtime video world model actually shipped to production

entry.title:

entry.summary: Ion Stoica introduces SkyLight, a framework that automatically discovers optimized sparse attention strategies, achieving SOTA performance from naive sliding-window baseline

entry.title: Talking to lots of folks across various professions using Claude Code, it is genuinely surprising, e...
entry.summary: Ethan Mollick reports that professionals using Claude Code are seeing a significant leap in LLM capability for real work over the past six weeks, urging AI skeptics to pay attention to these developments.

entry.title: Uhhh... I don't think Genie 3 is supposed to be generating Fortnite gameplay https://t.co/cBXn7s5pno
entry.summary: Matt Shumer shares surprising discovery that Genie 3 generates playable Fortnite gameplay, suggesting unexpected training data or capabilities

entry.title: Enjoy! Baked with our in-house inference kernels. We're going to migrate all our inference to GB 200...
entry.summary: Perplexity CEO Arav Srinivas announces they've built in-house inference kernels and will migrate all inference to GB200s (NVIDIA's latest) soon

entry.title: I feel like part of my shtick on BlueSky is to point out that yes, AI is real and it is especially i...
entry.summary: Mollick emphasizes that Claude Code/CLI tools will have very large impact, and argues that AI critics need to recognize AI is real rather than dismissing it as hype, as good criticism requires this acknowledgment.
